summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance for November 1, 2010.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Nov. 1, 2010

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & amplifications for Nov. 1, 2010

headline: CORRECTION
summary: The most recent public poll in California has state Proposition 24 with 31% support, 38% opposed and 31% undecided. A Oct. 29 editorial, "The Tax Me More State," said the initiative was ahead in the polls.

headline: Dan Quayle's Son Faces Tough Fight in House Race
summary: Arizona Republican Ben Quayle is running for Congress in a Republican district, in a Republican state, with the benefit of his party's momentum and a famous political name. But instead of sailing to an easy win, the son of former Vice President Dan Quayle is facing a turbulent election day.

headline: Rising Number of Voters Cast Early Ballots
summary: Even before Election Day on Tuesday. millions of early votes have been cast, though it's unclear which party will benefit. In some states, more than 40 percent of the ballots will be cast by early voters.

headline: Asia Mostly Higher, Though Tokyo Slips
summary: Asian stock markets ended mostly higher, with China and Hong Kong up sharply after solid manufacturing data in China. But a strong yen and iffy earnings outlooks sent the Nikkei down 0.5%..

headline: Medvedev Visits Disputed Island
summary: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev visited Kunashiri island Monday, one of the Russian-held islands also claimed by Japan.

headline: Salesforce.com Digs Deep for New Headquarters
summary: Business software developer Salesforce.com is paying $278 million for 14 acres of undeveloped land to build a new headquarters in San Francisco, the costliest land purchase in the city in years.

headline: Macau Gambling Revenue Surges
summary: Macau's October gambling revenue surged 50% from a year earlier, setting a record monthly high.

headline: Lawyers Gear Up for Post-Election Fights
summary: Political party lawyers are gearing up for what could be a heated post-election fight over the results of Tuesday's closest races.

headline: LinkedIn to Add Recommendation Service
summary: LinkedIn launched a recommendations service, which will allow the social network's members to post reviews of products and services linked to their professional profiles.

headline: Greater New York Watch
summary: Roundup of crime and court news

headline: Janet Jackson Follows Perry's Rainbow
summary: The actress and singer chats about her role in Tyler Perry's new film and her experience of shooting in New York.

headline: Tiananmen Crackdown Leader Honored
summary: A United Nations official who has courted controversy in the past has presented an award to the military leader of the 1989 crackdown on Tiananmen Square protests.

headline: Irish Court Rules Against Developer
summary: Ireland's high court ruled against property developer Patrick McKillen, effectively clearing the way for the country's state-loan agency to buy some  $2.92 billion of his property loans from Irish banks.

headline: Southeast Asian Cuisine
summary: Laut has more than 800 variations of dishes on its long menu, which offers Malaysian, Indonesian and Thai cuisine.

headline: PKK Denies Role in Istanbul Blast
summary: A group representing the Kurdish Workers Party, or PKK, denied responsibility for a weekend suicide-bomb attack in central Istanbul that wounded 32 people.

headline: SEC Probes J.P. Morgan Credit Deal
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a $1.1 billion deal sold by J.P. Morgan Chase, as part of a wider probe by the regulator into complex mortgage securities at the heart of the financial crisis.

headline: Vikings Release Randy Moss
summary: The wide receiver had not put up great numbers in his return to Minnesota.

headline: U.S. Manages Expectations for G-20 Talks
summary: The U.S. doesn't expect to resolve global tensions over China's currency policy or reach a final accord on economic imbalances at the Group of 20 industrialized and developing nations leaders' summit next week, White House and U.S. Treasury officials said Monday.

headline: Times Co. Issues Debt
summary: New York Times Co. plans to raise $225 million through a debt offering that will help the publisher pay back a loan from Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim.

headline: St. Joe Worries Resurface
summary: Options traders seemed to revisit their St. Joe Co. worries ahead of the Florida real-estate developer's earnings report.

headline: A Brief Encounter
summary: About 500 relatives from South and North Korea reunited this weekend at a mountain resort just inside the North's border for a brief encounter, after six decades of separation.

headline: China, India Manufacturing Surge
summary: Manufacturing in China and India continued to surge in October, bucking the trend in the rest of the Asia-Pacific region, where strong currencies and concerns over the health of the global economy are dragging down business sentiment.

headline: Source of Bomb-Plot Tip-Off Is Named
summary: The source of a tip that alerted security agencies around the world to the package-bomb plot late last week was Jabir al-Fayfi, a Saudi national and former Guantánamo Bay inmate.

headline: Campaigning Continues on Eve of Election
summary: President Barack Obama launched his final campaign swing Saturday by imploring voters to resist a Republican tide in the upcoming elections.

headline: Oil Firms on China Data
summary: Crude-oil futures rose on strong manufacturing data from China, but trading remained cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy announcement on Wednesday.

headline: News Corp. Takes Stake in Rubicon
summary: News Corp. has obtained a minority stake in Rubicon Project, a Web advertising firm, in exchange for its online ad group Fox Audience Network.

headline: Allergan Swings to Loss on Botox Deal
summary: Allergan swung to a third-quarter loss as the company booked charges to settle allegations regarding past Botox sales and marketing practices.

headline: Gold Falls Amid Upbeat News
summary: Upbeat U.S. economic data and a stronger dollar weighed on Comex gold prices, as some traders worried the positive news will reduce long-awaited Federal Reserve stimulus.

headline: Photos of the Day: Nov. 1
summary: In Monday's pictures, Bulgarian students protest education cuts, separated Koreans say tearful goodbyes, a Pakistani boy celebrates a good fishing catch and more.

headline: Baker Hughes Profit Jumps Amid Acquisition
summary: Baker Hughes said earnings soared as the oilfield-services company benefited from the April acquisition of BJ Services.

headline: Dynegy's Blackstone Buyout Approved
summary: Dynegy Inc. said the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved its plan to be acquired by Blackstone Group LP and sell four gas-fueled plants to NRG Energy Inc.

headline: Stock Catalysts Go Beyond Fed, Election
summary: Despite some investor worries, there are catalysts beyond this week's highly anticipated events that could continue to push stocks higher.

headline: Miners Drive Europe's Stock Gains
summary: European stocks closed marginally higher as better-than-anticipated U.S. and Chinese economic data helped bolster hopes about the global recovery.

headline: Nissan Seeks Image Boost With Leaf
summary: Nissan is counting on its soon-to-be-launched Leaf electric car to create a new image for the company, which is traditionally viewed as the No. 3 Japanese auto maker behind Toyota and Honda.

headline: European Clearing Reform Dealt Late Setback
summary: A long-awaited agreement between four of Europe's leading clearing houses has been postponed by European regulators at the last minute, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Regulator Calls for Curbs on Financial Futures
summary: CFTC Commissioner Bart Chilton said the limits could help prevent a repeat of the May 6 'flash crash.'

headline: Taobao Mall Gets Own Site
summary: Alibaba created a new domain for its Taobao Mall Chinese business-to-consumer portal, separating the brand from the company's consumer-to-consumer site to give the retail site more prominence.

headline: Allied Irish Stake Sale on Hold
summary: Allied Irish Banks' proposed sale of its U.K. business is on hold due to insufficient bids, new Chairman David Hodgkinson said.

headline: Focus on Cargo Security Steps
summary: The discovery of sophisticated explosive devices in packages that were bound for the U.S. highlights significant gaps in cargo screening both domestically and overseas, adding to pressure for security improvements.

headline: A Star is Made in Hong Kong
summary: Fast-growing Chinese drug company Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holdings got almost no attention on the Singapore stock market. So it moved to Hong Kong, where its stock price and trading volume shot up. The lure of Hong Kong is what Singapore Exchanges hopes to counter by bulking up with a purchase of the Australian stock-market operator.

headline: China Gives Hong Kong Investor License
summary: China's securities regulator said it approved an application from Hong Kong's de facto central bank that would allow the territory to diversify its foreign-exchange reserves into the Chinese yuan.

headline: South Africa Swears in New Ministers
summary: New South African ministers were sworn in Monday after the first major shuffle of President Jacob Zuma's cabinet since taking office 17 months ago.

headline: Package Bombs Help U.S.  Defense in Cleric Case
summary: The latest bombing attempt from Yemen could strengthen the Obama administration's defense against a lawsuit challenging alleged government efforts to kill Yemeni-American cleric Anwar al Awlaki.

headline: ICE Profit Up 10%
summary: Third-quarter earnings at IntercontinentalExchange rose 10% as the exchange operator saw higher volume and increased revenue.

headline: AEP, MidAmerican Plan Transmission Projects
summary: A joint venture of American Electric Power and Berkshire Hathaway's MidAmerican Energy plans to develop two extra high-voltage transmission projects to cost $2.25 billion.

headline: Iraqi Christians in Mourning
summary: Iraqi security forces stormed a Baghdad church where militants had taken an entire congregation hostage for four hours, leaving at least 52 people dead.

headline: U.K. Extends Business-Loan Guarantees
summary: The U.K. government set out initiatives to help small businesses, including extending for four years a loan-guarantee program started by the previous administration.

headline: Obama Aims to Boost Turnout
summary: President Barack Obama rallied a crowd of Democratic volunteers in Philadelphia in a final weekend of campaigning aimed at turning out voters most likely to support Democrats in Tuesday's elections.

headline: This One's On Them
summary: Fans who shoot, edit and distribute concert video for free online are re-writing the music industry rulebook.

headline: Ditching Politics for Entrepreneurship
summary: Young staffers who helped President Obama win office are now using skills from the campaign trail to launch their own ventures.

headline: M&T To Acquire Ailing Wilmington Trust
summary: Wilmington Trust, a once-stellar trust bank, said it would sell itself for less than book value and for roughly half the price its shares fetched on Friday.

headline: BHP Unlikely to Raise Potash Bid
summary: BHP Billiton is unlikely to alter the terms of its $39 billion offer for Potash before it gets regulatory approval from Canadian authorities, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Paris Dining in NYC
summary: Le Relais de Venise "L'Entrecote," the Manhattan outpost of a 51-year-old bistro in Paris, aims to copy almost all of the details of the French original, from the floor tiles to the hand-chipped frites.

headline: Global Chip Sales Rise 2.9% From Prior Month
summary: Global chip sales rose 2.9% in September from a month earlier, the seventh straight period of sequential gains, as results for the third quarter rose 6.1% from the spring, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association.

headline: Austin with a View
summary: Large expanses of windows in this 6,400-square-foot home in Austin take advantage of lovely lake views.

headline: Beauty Firm's Profit Rises
summary: Alberto-Culver, which is about to be absorbed by Unilever PLC, said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 31%. Sales at the maker of hair-care and personal-care products increased 12%.

headline: Smurfit Profit Drops 4.4%
summary: Smurfit-Stone Container's third-quarter earnings fell 4.4% as income-tax provisions pinched the packaging company's results.

headline: Packages Spark Security Concerns
summary: Authorities intercepted two U.S.-bound packages laden with explosives in cargo shipments from Yemen, raising alarm in the U.S. and Europe at a time when counterterrorism officials say they are closely tracking multiple suspected terror plots by al Qaeda and its affiliates.

headline: U.K. Manufacturing Picks Up
summary: The U.K. manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace in October for the first time since March, boosted by a sharp increase in export orders.

headline: TNT Posts 24% Fall in Profit
summary: Dutch postal and express group TNT reported its third-quarter net profit slipped 24% due to price pressure in its express business and higher pension costs.

headline: Cooper Tire's Profit Falls
summary: Cooper Tire's third-quarter earnings fell 4.8% as higher costs for raw materials more than offset price and revenue increases.

headline: African Polls Show Volatility of Democracy
summary: Voters in Ivory Coast on Sunday cast ballots in the west African nation's first presidential election in a decade, while across the continent in East Africa, Tanzanians participated in their fourth successive election, underscoring how varied, and volatile, African democracy still is.

headline: Humana Net Up 30%; Claims Costs Fall
summary: Humana's third-quarter profit rose 30% as revenue rose on increases in enrollment.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields firmed as some investors trimmed their exposure to government debt ahead of Tuesday's 10-year auction.

headline: Emirates Airline's Profit Soars
summary: Emirates Airline reported a more than four-fold increase in first-half net profit as it invested in new aircraft and carried more cargo and passengers.

headline: Tests Loom for BHP-Potash Deal
summary: A series of regulator and court decisions in the coming week may guide how BHP Billiton proceeds with its $39 billion hostile bid for Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan.

headline: ONGC Seeks 2-for-1 Stock Split
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp. has sought the Indian government's permission for a two-for-one stock split ahead of its follow-on public offering, as the state-run company wants to make its share price attractive to retail investors.

headline: India PM: Pushing to Secure Global Fuel Assets
summary: The Indian government is encouraging state-run oil companies to buy stakes in overseas energy assets to help secure supplies of fossil fuels to power a fast-expanding economy, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said.

headline: Maruti, TVS, Hyundai Post Record Sales
summary: Most Indian auto makers posted record monthly sales in October as the festive season drew more customers to showrooms, prompting dealers to stock up to meet soaring demand.

headline: Harmony Gold Swings to Profit
summary: Harmony Gold Mining, South Africa's third-largest gold producer, said it swung to a profit in the fiscal first quarter following the disposal of a mine.

headline: Nothing says 'I love you' like a prenup
summary: A high-profile ruling in Britain's Supreme Court last month has inspired a spate of interest in legal pre-wedding agreements. Here are her tips on drawing up a prenup.

headline: India Mobile Number Portability from Nov 25
summary: India will implement mobile number portability, which will allow users to switch service providers while retaining their phone number, on Nov. 25.

headline: Will Lafite's Red '8' be lucky in China?
summary: In a nod to its Chinese customers Château Lafite-Rothschild will feature the Chinese character of the numeral eight on its vintage 2008 bottles, which ship next year.

headline: ArcelorMittal: Committed to Eastern India Plant
summary: ArcelorMittal said the company is committed to setting up of a 12-million-ton-a-year steel plant in the eastern Indian state of Jharkhand.

headline: Giants Win 4-0 Over Rangers
summary: Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner threw eight shutout innings to lead his team to a 4-0 win over the Rangers and one game away from a World Series title.

headline: China Rongsheng to Revive Hong Kong IPO
summary: Shipbuilder China Rongsheng Heavy Industries is restarting an IPO cancelled in 2008 and is seeking to raise US$2.28 billion.

headline: 25 Years' Worth of Lint
summary: There are few items of domestic existence that generate the mellow satisfaction of removing the fuzzy stuff from your dryer's lint screen.

headline: IPO Momentum Could Continue After Elections
summary: After wrapping up the busiest month in three years, the U.S. IPO market could see even more activity after midterm elections wrap up.

summary: For his new dance work, "Sutra," choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui combined the ancient movements of Chinese king fu and the buddhist embrace of modernity and open-mindedness.

headline: Consumers Spend and Market Shrugs
summary: Survey after survey shows consumer confidence mired at near-recessionary levels. Yet Friday's GDP figures show consumer spending continues to accelerate. This has garnered little notice.

headline: Defending Champs Next Up for Rangers
summary: The Rangers get their biggest test of the season Monday when they host the defending Stanley Cup champion Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: Turkey Suggests It Won't Block Shield
summary: Turkey's Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said it was "out of the question" for Turkey to oppose security measures NATO considers necessary, apparently ruling out any move to block a missile shield the U.S. is proposing for the military alliance.

headline: Crovitz: Journalism Scoops Wikileaks
summary: There's little of public benefit in the documents that hadn't already been reported.

headline: Voters Weigh Property-Tax Caps
summary: Indiana voters are likely Tuesday to enshrine new property-tax caps in the state constitution with an amendment that would make them permanent, adding to pressures on municipal budgets already suffering.

headline: Fox, Cablevision Reach Agreement
summary: Cablevision and Fox Networks reached an agreement ending a two-week stalemate marked by heated rhetoric, legal actions and missed sporting events.

headline: The Many Powers of Maybe
summary: Electronic invites are making it way too easy for us to wriggle out of social engagements -- and it says a lot about us.

headline: Bosses Overestimate Their Skills
summary: A new survey of 1,100 front-line managers suggests many are over-estimating their skills, with surprisingly little self-doubt.

headline: Apple Sues Motorola Over Patents
summary: Apple sued Motorola alleging the company's smartphone lineup infringes on the iPhone maker's intellectual property.

headline: Developer Recaptures a Maritime Motif
summary: Frank Fusaro embarked on a historical reclamation mission of sorts when he took on the job of designing the new Dream Downtown hotel now taking shape in Chelsea with its distinctive punched-out porthole windows.

headline: U.K. Pays High Price to Save Euro
summary: If subjecting Britain to fines if the eurocracy doesn't approve of its fiscal policy, and being able to call on British cash for bailouts isn't a further transfer of sovereignty from Britain to Brussels, it is difficult to tell what is.

headline: Colombia Sets Ambitious Oil Agenda
summary: Colombia is capping a string of military victories against Marxist guerrillas with a lucrative peace dividend: oil production.

headline: Limited Government: This Means You
summary: I've got a message for Rep. Darrell Issa, Rep. Kevin McCarthy and Oregon State Rep. Scott Bruun: Tea party voters aren't interested in working with liberals, socialists and others who reject America's founding principals ("GOP House Leaders Seek to Avoid Mistakes of '94," page one, Oct. 19).

headline: Videogames as Free-Speech Issue
summary: The Supreme Court will consider whether to strip First Amendment protection from violent videogames that critics say appeal to the deviant interests of children.

headline: Kaminski: Who's Afraid of Marco Rubio?
summary: Democrats are scared enough of the charismatic Republican Senate hopeful that some were willing to sacrifice their own candidate to help a stronger challenger in the race.

headline: Vote Hints at Historic Political Volatility
summary: The U.S. could be caught in a cycle of political volatility witnessed only four times in the past century, almost all during war or economic unease.

headline: Scott Rasmussen: A Vote Against Dems, Not for the GOP
summary: Voters don't want to be governed from the left, right or center. They want Washington to recognize that Americans want to govern themselves.

headline: ICBC Growth Helps Bolster Office Sector
summary: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China is expanding in the U.S., and that's a bit of good news for the Manhattan office market.

headline: On Judging the Selection of Judges
summary: Regarding your editorial "Soros Bets on Nevada" (Oct. 22): Justice at Stake does not support one system of selecting judges. Our partnership includes supporters of both merit selection and other reforms, such as public financing of judicial elections.

headline: Haiti Braces for Storm
summary: Haiti is bracing for the arrival of a storm that could complicate its efforts to control a cholera outbreak, and expose hundreds of thousands living in tent cities to high winds and heavy rains.

headline: Ads Jockey for Time
summary: The influx of political spending has forced many consumer ads off the air, frustrating some marketers.

headline: Indonesia Volcano Hinders Aid Work
summary: Aid workers responding to one of Indonesia's latest natural disasters are gearing up for a longer-than-expected relief effort, as they grapple with a volatile volcano that experts say may stay active for weeks.

headline: Far From Home Improvement
summary: Charity begins at home. Until the bust, home-improvement companies profited from the kindness. The problem now is that many Americans are unlikely to expect a return on home improvements for a while.

headline: Michaels Weighs Comeback Plans
summary: Former Tribune CEO Randy Michaels is considering a return to the media industry after leaving Tribune amid unflattering accounts of its corporate culture.

headline: Keeping the Party Going at Viacom
summary: Viacom has gotten its momentum back, thanks to "Jersey Shore" and other shows on MTV. In a Boss Talk interview, CEO Philippe Dauman talks about keeping things going.

headline: RUC Is the Wave of the Future for American Medicine
summary: The American Medical Association is proud to convene the Relative Value Scale Update Committee, or RUC, a group of volunteer physicians who provide expertise to Medicare, saving taxpayers millions ("Secrets of the System: Physician Panel Prescribes the Fees Paid by Medicare," page one, Oct. 27).

headline: In Search of Nature's Treats
summary: Evan Strusinski is a food forager who scours forests, rivers, swamps and bogs for obscure ingredients sought by high-end restaurants.

headline: Hong Kong Yuan Quota Depleted
summary: Hong Kong companies have already exhausted their full-year quota of yuan to settle trades, underscoring the rush by companies and investors in the territory for the mainland currency on expectations it will keep rising.

headline: Soccer's Biggest Signings
summary: The biggest deals in soccer used to be multimillion dollar transfers to land the sport's biggest stars. These days, arguably the most important signings for Europe's top clubs are the sponsors on the front of their uniforms.

headline: New Euro-Zone Rules Could Backfire
summary: European leaders are determined to avoid a rerun of this year's euro zone sovereign-debt crisis. But will the cure prove as bad as the disease?

headline: Clinton Presses Cambodia on China
summary: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton pressed Cambodia to remain independent of China on key economic and environmental issues.

headline: The Newest Heart Test Is Low-Tech
summary: Expensive medical tests like CT scans help doctors better diagnose disease. But sometimes the best tools physicians use are decidedly low-tech, like a tape measure or bathroom scale.

headline: Ukrainians Vote in Local Elections
summary: Ukrainians voted in local elections that were viewed as the first test of President Viktor Yanukovych's popularity and commitment to democracy since taking office in February.

headline: Muni Issuers Are Slow on Audits, Study Finds
summary: Municipal bond issuers' audited financial statements typically take about twice as long to reach investors as comparable data from corporate borrowers, a research firm has found.

headline: Voice Lessons in Customer  Service
summary: In an attempt to improve automated customer-service lines, companies are investing in warmer, more-competent sounding voice recordings.

headline: Cultural Boards Get Younger Look
summary: New York's elite cultural boards are getting a more youthful look as institutions add increasing numbers of trustees under 40.

headline: Frustrated Defenders Do Everything but Win
summary: One of the Jets' soundest defensive performances of the season, against a better-than-average Packers offense, went to waste in the 9-0 defeat.

headline: City Holds Place In Global Markets
summary: New York City has roughly kept its place in the ranking of the most expensive office markets, rising slightly to sixth place this year from seventh place two years ago.

headline: Rousseff Elected President in Brazil
summary: Dilma Rousseff, a 62-year-old former leftist guerilla-turned-powerful cabinet minister, was elected Brazil's first female president in a lopsided victory.

headline: Hamburg Equestrian Estate
summary: Gut Ballin is a country estate with an Olympic-size horse-riding arena in Trittau, a scenic rural haven 30 minutes from Hamburg.

headline: 3M Balances New and Old
summary: 3M is using acquisitions and its own labs to diversify into such areas as biometrics and fuel cells. But the 108-year-old company also has updated one of its original products: industrial-grade sandpaper.

headline: Fans Let LeBron Have It, But He Has Last Laugh
summary: LeBron James showed up four months too late for these 17,086 fans, so they showed him plenty of venom. But in the Heat's 101-78 victory, the Nets themselves didn't show much.

headline: Safety Crackdown Hits Mining Profits
summary: A U.S. regulatory crackdown that followed an April mining explosion that killed 29 workers in West Virginia is cutting into profits at coal mining companies.

headline: WTC Taps Fuel Cells
summary: The six fuel cells that will provide about 30% of the power for towers 3 and 4 of the World Trade Center office complex would make the site one of the biggest fuel-cell installations in the world.

headline: Nasdaq, VIX Creator Plan 'Alpha Indexes'
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group plans to introduce new indexes from the creator of the VIX "fear gauge" that will track popular stocks' performance against the broader market.

headline: Roche's Plan for Rivals
summary: Roche CEO Severin Schwan is preparing the Swiss drug giant for a battle it hasn't faced before: competition from generic copies of its cancer-fighting biotech drugs.

headline: Car Insurers' Pricing Practices Under Fire
summary: Car insurers' use of credit histories to decide what to charge customers has been controversial for years. Now, consumer advocates are trying to draw attention to other factors they dislike, including occupation and education.

headline: Donen Goes Back On the Town
summary: Filmmaking pioneer Stanley Donen will be the subject of a tribute series at the Film Society of Lincoln Center that will span his directorial career through the 1970s.

headline: Why Annuity Swaps Often Backfire
summary: Holders of variable annuities who do an exchange could be getting an annuity with higher expenses and more restrictions—and in some cases may be giving up guaranteed payments that built up in the bear market.

headline: Pros and Cons of Closed-End Funds
summary: These investments can be great bargains. But too many people buy blindly—and get burned.

headline: One Giant Leap for San Francisco
summary: The San Francisco Giants topped the Texas Rangers by a 3-1 score in Game 5 of the World Series to give the team its first world championship since its 1950s move to San Francisco.

headline: Counterterror Chief Says U.S. Must Be Vigilant
summary: President Obama's counterterrorism adviser said authorities must presume there might be more bombs like the ones pulled from cargo planes headed to the U.S. from Yemen last week.

headline: ETF Initials Can Be a Puzzle
summary: Labels on exchange-traded funds can be quite a mouthful, as they echo the details of narrower and narrower indexes.

headline: I'm Nobody! Who Are You? Are You a Nobody, Too?
summary: The front-page article "Foes Plan Post-Vote Deals" (Oct. 28) quotes Will Marshall of the "Democratic centrist" Progressive Policy Institute as saying, "The voters who matter most do not want to see a continuation of the paralyzation of American politics."

headline: BofA Tries to Untangle Mortgage Files
summary: Bank of America employees are slogging through 102,000 foreclosure files, one of the side effects of the bank's 2008 acquisition of Countrywide.

headline: State's Swing Status Put to Test
summary: North Carolina was among the swing states that appeared to be trending blue in 2008, but it may be reddening as Rep. McIntyre battles Pantano.
